Though the proposed Smather Bill would not affect the State
University of Iowa at this moment, it could create a great problem
in the future. We do not now have a University Press but are quite
hopeful of getting one in the not-too-distant future. When we do,
one of its major projects will be the publication of original
symphonies and other musical works.
As you might know, one of the outstanding areas at the Univer¬
sity of Iowa is its Department of Music. One of this department's
most inportant activities is composition. These compositions are
even accepted as dissertations at the PhD level. We would hope
that our University Press would be able to publish those compositions
of students and of faculty members which are worthy of distribution
and which no other publishing house would find profitable.
We would not like to jeopardize the future of our present broad¬
casting facilities nor those which we propose. Nor, on the other
hand, would we like to see this important creative musical activity
stifled. For these reasons, Harry, I hope that the NAEB will do
everything possible to see that if the Smathers Bill is enacted,
it will exempt educational institutions from its provisions.
Sincerely,
Sam L. Becker
